deltas.text: A voltage source supplies EMF (electromotive force) to a circuit.
This manifests as a constant voltage across the voltage source, enforced by the voltage source.
An ideal voltage source can supply an arbitrary amount of current through it; however, most real voltage sources cannot supply infinite current.
During analysis, we usually assume a voltage source can supply any value of current except infinity, which occurs when a voltage source is shorted.
Please imagine the voltage source exploding. (Real voltage sources usually just rapidly discharge instead of blowing up.)
If your voltage source has safeguards against shorts, it will instead output a lower voltage than listed. [END]
